title: Reading Comprehension: Fiction Stories

vocab.definition: Stories that are made up or imagined, not real
A person or animal in a story
When and where a story takes place
The sequence of events that happen in a story
The most important point or message of a story
The message or lesson the story teaches
The problem or challenge a character faces
The turning point or most exciting moment
How the main problem is solved at the end
The beginning that introduces the setting and characters
Events that build up to the climax
Events after the climax that lead to the end
Who is telling the story (like first person)

teachingNotes: Practice identifying story elements. Use graphic organizers to help students track characters, setting, and plot. Encourage students to make predictions while reading.

sample.question: What do we call stories that are made up or imagined?
Which story part introduces the characters and setting?
The setting tells us when and where a story happens.
The sequence of events in a story is called the ________.
Which is most likely a theme?
A problem the character faces is called a ________.
Whose point of view uses words like 'I' and 'me'?
The ending of the story where the conflict is solved is the ________.
In a story, the time and place are called the ________.
Which event usually comes last in a plot?

truefalse.question: The setting tells us when and where a story happens.
The plot is the list of characters in a story.
A theme is a message or lesson in the story.
First-person point of view uses 'he' and 'she' to tell the story.
Characters can be people, animals, or even objects in a story.
The climax usually happens at the beginning of the story.
Dialogue is what characters say to each other.
The resolution is where new problems are introduced.
Setting can include the time period, like 'long ago' or 'the future'.
The main character is always the narrator.
